htmlEmbed:
Sea level to rise one foot along U.S. coastlines by 2050, government report findsThe Washington Post1/15/2022

Sea levels along the United States' shorelines will increase as much by 2050 as they did over the past century, according to a report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Climate & EnvironmentRead

target=_blank>flooding</a> and erosion to coastal communities across the country, according to a <a href="https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/hazards/sealevelrise/sealevelrise-tech-report.html" target=_blank>report released Tuesday</a> by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.</p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class=" b bh bc-gray-lighter mb-md hide-for-print" data-qa="subscribe-promo"><a class="pt-sm pb-sm flex items-center bold font-xxxs font-xxs-ns offblack hover-blue-bright justify-between" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/02/22/climate-change-actions-carbon-footprint/?itid=lk_cta_ssinline" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" style="border:none"><span class="mr-xs flex items-center"><span class="ml-xs">10 steps you can take to lower your carbon footprint</span></span><svg class="content-box" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" style="transition:right .2s;position:relative;right:4px;fill:#666" aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" role="img"><title>ArrowRight</title><path d="M7.664 1.25l6 data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Human-caused climate change, driven mostly by the burning of fossil fuels, has accelerated global sea level rise to the fastest rate in more than 3,000 years. The report by NOAA, NASA and five other federal agencies — updating a study from 2017 — predicts that ocean levels along U.S. coasts will increase as much by 2050 as they did over the past century.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-video" class="ma-auto" style="max-width:300px"><div><figure class="pt-xs mb-md mr-auto-ns ml-auto-ns hide-for-print
    flex flex-column items-center"><div class="powa-wrapper" style="width:100%;height:0;background-size:contain;padding-bottom:177.77777777777777%;background-color:rgb(245, 245, 245);background-image:url(https://www.washingtonpost.com/player/prod/img/video-thumbnail-bg.png);background-position:center;background-repeat:no-repeat"></div><figcaption class="mt-xs mr-auto-ns ml-auto-ns left gray-dark font--subhead font-xxxs square-vertical-video" data-qa="video-caption">Deputy weather editor Kasha Patel breaks down a study that visualized what Earth could look like if global temperatures rise by 1.5 or 3 degrees Celsius. (Video: Casey Silvestri/The Washington Post, Photo: The Washington Post)</figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">This amount of water battering the coasts “will create a profound increase in the frequency of coastal flooding, even in the absence of storms or heavy rainfall,” NOAA said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“We’re unfortunately headed for a flood regime shift,” said William Sweet, an oceanographer at the NOAA National Ocean Service and the nation’s top scientist on sea level rise. “There will be water in the streets unless action is taken in more and more communities.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Drawing on data from tidal gauges and satellite imagery as well as cutting-edge models from the most recent United Nations report on climate change, the NOAA analysis gives decade-by-decade projections for sea-level rise for all U.S. states and territories over the next 100 years. Advances in ice sheet modeling and better observational data allowed the authors to give more definitive near-term projections than ever before, Sweet said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Even if the world takes swift action to curb carbon emissions, he said, the trajectory for sea level rise “is more or less set over the next 30 years.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Kristina Dahl, a principal climate scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists, said research she and colleagues have done suggest that 10 to 12 inches of sea level rise by 2050 would put roughly 140,000 homes at risk of “chronic inundation,” or flooding every other week on average.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Already, she said, high-tide flooding in places such as Charleston, S.C., has quadrupled in frequency since the 1970s. Other regions, from Louisiana to New Jersey to the Eastern Shore of Maryland, have wrestled with flooding that has become more common and costly.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“They’re already having to make difficult decisions or major investments to cope with the flooding they are seeing,” said Dahl, who was not involved in Tuesday’s report. While other coastal communities have avoided major impacts, “they will have to start grappling with these same kind of issues.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" report: High-tide flooding could happen ‘every other day’ by late this century</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Looking ahead to the end of the century, the amount of planet-warming pollution people release into the atmosphere could mean the difference between sea levels stabilizing at about two feet above the historical average or surging by almost eight feet, NOAA reports.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“This report is a wake-up call for the U.S., but it’s a wake-up call with a silver lining,” NOAA Administrator <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2021/04/22/biden-noaa-administrator-rick-spinrad/?itid=lk_inline_manual_19" target=_blank>Rick Spinrad</a> told journalists in a teleconference Tuesday. “It provides us with information needed to act now to best position ourselves for the future.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">In years past, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/08/23/tennessee-floods-show-pressing-climate-danger-across-america-wall-water/?itid=lk_inline_manual_21" target="_blank">powerful storms pushing water up shorelines</a> were the primary drivers of flooding along coasts. But as surging seas raise the level of high tides, communities from the Gulf Coast and the Pacific Northwest to the beaches of Hawaii and the barrier islands of North Carolina increasingly suffer from “sunny day” floods, when saltwater bubbles up from storm drains and spills into streets without a drop of rain.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" colleagues found that U.S. coastlines experience twice as much high-tide flooding as they did just 20 years ago.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">By the middle of the century, the new NOAA analysis finds, minor high-tide flooding events could happen more than 10 times a year. More significant and destructive events, which currently have about a 4 percent chance of happening in a given year, could occur twice a decade.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“What we are trying to communicate to folks is these are real-life impacts that will influence their day-to-day decision-making,” Sweet said.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Coastal communities must start planning for regular inundation, scientists warned, especially in places where coastal development and sinking land compound the risks of sea level rise.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Storm and wastewater systems may need to be upgraded to cope with the influx of seawater. Homes and important infrastructure located within the new upper bounds of high tides might have to relocate.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The consequences could go beyond floods. Saltwater threatens to infiltrate coastal aquifers, affecting water quality and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/ruined-crops-salty-soil-how-rising-seas-are-poisoning-north-carolinas-farmland/2019/03/01/2e26b83e-28ce-11e9-8eef-0d74f4bf0295_story.html?itid=lk_inline_manual_31" target="_blank">sterilizing farm fields</a>. The septic systems used in many coastal communities <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/12/17/climate-solutions-sewage/?itid=lk_inline_manual_31" target="_blank">won’t be able to safely handle waste</a> as water tables rise.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Ports could see severe damage, said NOAA National Ocean Service Director Nicole LeBoeuf — disrupting supply chains and raising costs even for people who live hundreds of miles from coastlines.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div data-qa="article-image" class="hide-for-print"><div style="min-height:358px"></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">While Tuesday’s report makes clear that a certain amount of sea level rise is essentially guaranteed based on the world’s past emissions, Dahl said that reality only underscores the importance of reducing greenhouse gas pollution.</p></div><div class="article-body" future.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center levels — the most ambitious goal of the Paris climate agreement.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">If nations fail to hit that target, she said, it risks destabilizing the Antarctic ice sheet and creating conditions for catastrophic amounts of sea level rise in the future.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">The reports finds that if warming exceeds 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, there’s at least a 50 percent chance of sea level rise exceeding 1.6 feet on average globally by 2100. With 3 to 5 degrees Celsius of warming, that likelihood balloons to 80 to 99 percent. The sea level rise in the United States would be near or higher than the global average.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Compared with NOAA’s sea level rise projections made in 2017, the new estimates are largely unchanged through 2100. However, the expected rate of sea level rise is slightly slower through 2050, before accelerating toward the end of the century. The agency also eliminated an “extreme” scenario of over eight feet of sea level rise by 2100 that it now considers implausible.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p><span class="font--article-body font-copy hide-for-print ma-0 pb-md db italic interstitial"><a data-qa="interstitial-link" href="https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/#/bundle/energy?method=SURL&location=ART&itid=lk_interstitial_manual_45">Sign up for the latest news about climate change, energy and the environment, delivered every Thursday</a></span></p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Reide Corbett, dean of Integrated Coastal Programs at East Carolina University and executive director at Coastal Studies Institute, said the NOAA report is important because it so clearly and definitively details a real-world threat posed by climate change.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb db dn-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-sm pt-sm pb-sm" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“We need to make people understand this isn’t just a bunch of scientists talking and arm-waving. This is really happening, and it’s happening on time scales that matter to the individual,” said Corbett, who was not involved in the study.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class="cb dn db-ns" data-qa="article-body-ad"><div aria-hidden="true" class="hide-for-print relative flex justify-center content-box items-center b bh mb-md mt-none pt-lg pb-lg" style="min-height:250px;border-top-color:;border-bottom-color:"><div class="center absolute w-100 border-box" style="top:"><div class="dib gray-dark pl-xs pr-xs font-sans-serif light font-xxxxs lh-md" style="--primary-border-color:"></div></div><div data-testid="placeholder-box" class="w-100 h-100 absolute flex flex-column justify-center border-box bg-offwhite" style="width:300px;height:250px"><div class="flex flex-column justify-center font-sans-serif center font-xxs light gray-dark lh-md"><div>Advertisement</div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“If we’re talking about 2050 — for someone buying a house today, that’s within the range of their mortgage.”</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">For Corbett, who lives on the flood-prone Outer Banks of North Carolina, the prospect of sea level rise is deeply personal. Just last week, he said, beach erosion caused a house in nearby Rodanthe to <a href="https://www.wcnc.com/article/weather/beach-erosion-cause-home-collapse-outer-banks/275-3ef646f9-95d4-4f64-903b-3f9513bc36c3" target=_blank>collapse into the sea</a>.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">He hoped the NOAA findings will spur vulnerable communities to invest in adaptation measures — restoring ecosystems that help hold back floodwaters, rerouting roads and bridges to steer away from the most vulnerable spots. In some cases, he said, communities will have to make hard decisions about what places are worth protecting and when it’s time to retreat.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">“We need to really start working through these challenging conversations now,” he said. “Not right after the next storm, but before.”</p></div><div class="mb-lg-mod hide-for-print" id="link-box"><div data-qa="content" class="linkbox-content"><h3 class="font-md font-bold font--headline offblack lh-md pb-xs" data-qa="linkbox-headline">More on climate change</h3><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Learn more</b>: <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2019/national/climate-environment/thermometers-climate-change/" target=_blank>How we know global warming is real</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/interactive/2022/united-nations-ipcc-climate-change-postcards/" target=_blank>Postcards from Earth’s climate futures</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/10/22/climate-curious-disasters-climate-change/" target=_blank>The undeniable link between weather disasters and climate change</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/interactive/2021/climate-change-humidity/" target=_blank>How climate change is making parts of the world too hot and humid to survive</a></p><p class="font-xxs gray-darkest lh-md ma-0 pb-xs pt-xs mt-xxs mb-xxs linkbox-content-item"><b>Tips</b>: <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/wellness/climate-change-anxiety-dread-cope/2021/07/14/471eb264-e4d4-11eb-b722-89ea0dde7771_story.html" target=_blank>How to cope with your anxiety about climate change</a> | <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2021/03/30/climate-curious-electric-cars/">Thinking of buying an electric vehicle? The report by NOAA, NASA and five other federal agencies — updating a study from 2017 — predicts that ocean levels along U.S. coasts will increase as much by 2050 as they did over the past century.","type":"text","originalIdx":2},{"_id":"16321794-b5fd-4981-ab85-24956da20e82","additional_properties":{"embedContinuousPlay":false},"canonical_url":"/video/climate-environment/sea-levels-are-rising-around-the-world-heres-how-high-they-could-reach/2021/10/29/16321794-b5fd-4981-ab85-24956da20e82_video.html","credits":{"by":[{"name":"Casey Silvestri","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/casey-silvestri/","additional_properties":{"original":{"expertise":"Video Producer, Instagram","image":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/arc-authors/washpost/d50aac84-1126-418b-9ad0-972491618ad7.jpeg"}}}]},"credits_caption_display":"Deputy weather editor Kasha Patel breaks down a study that visualized what Earth could look like if global temperatures rise by 1.5 or 3 degrees Celsius. (NASA-JPL/Caltech) ","distributor":{"category":"handout"},"height":739,"image_type":"photograph","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/F6OTPDTBCNCLVE22NIHAY7RVKA.PNG","width":1402,"originalIdx":6},{"_id":"W64ONTLMERCVJMFIGVIHLEKODU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Drawing on data from tidal gauges and satellite imagery as well as cutting-edge models from the most recent United Nations report on climate change, the NOAA analysis gives decade-by-decade projections for sea-level rise for all U.S. states and territories over the next 100 years. Advances in ice sheet modeling and better observational data allowed the authors to give more definitive near-term projections than ever before, Sweet said.","type":"text","originalIdx":7},{"_id":"QGGJB2P2G5DWRK27CE26PJOK2Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"Even if the world takes swift action to curb carbon emissions, he said, the trajectory for sea level rise “is more or less set over the next 30 years.”","type":"text","originalIdx":8},{"_id":"3MG6NAD7J5G6TD7MCCGRECI4XA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Kristina Dahl, a principal climate scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists, said research she and colleagues have done suggest that 10 to 12 inches of sea level rise by 2050 would put roughly 140,000 homes at risk of “chronic inundation,” or flooding every other week on average.","type":"text","originalIdx":9},{"_id":"2LZJKOUFHJAKBJOXEOG2ALZBKA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Already, she said, high-tide flooding in places such as Charleston, S.C., has quadrupled in frequency since the 1970s. Other regions, from Louisiana to New Jersey to the Eastern Shore of Maryland, have wrestled with flooding that has become more common and costly.","type":"text","originalIdx":10},{"_id":"DCCJUJTM2RCMFBBQ6OK4ZXH6FA","additional_properties":{},"content":"“They’re already having to make difficult decisions or major investments to cope with the flooding they are seeing,” said Dahl, who was not involved in Tuesday’s report. While other coastal communities have avoided major impacts, “they will have to start grappling with these same kind of issues.”","type":"text","originalIdx":11},{"_id":"MJ5CPNYQORBPDDQLRI4RLOGD3U","additional_properties":{},"content":"Federal report: High-tide flooding could happen ‘every other day’ by late this century","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/capital-weather-gang/wp/2018/03/28/federal-report-high-tide-flooding-could-happen-every-other-day-by-late-this-century/","originalIdx":12},{"_id":"GPYGHSI6K5EAHCAEKFGABX7ITE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Looking ahead to the end of the century, the amount of planet-warming pollution people release into the atmosphere could mean the difference between sea levels stabilizing at about two feet above the historical average or surging by almost eight feet, NOAA reports.","type":"text","originalIdx":13},{"_id":"GUVSSBD4JBAEJMUC7TUNLOAGT4","additional_properties":{},"content":"“This report is a wake-up call for the U.S., but it’s a wake-up call with a silver lining,” NOAA Administrator \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2021/04/22/biden-noaa-administrator-rick-spinrad/\" target=_blank\u003eRick Spinrad\u003c/a\u003e told journalists in a teleconference Tuesday. “It provides us with information needed to act now to best position ourselves for the future.”","type":"text","originalIdx":14},{"_id":"M3UQEQD6YQI6ZPYC7HREZTXRJE","additional_properties":{"keywords":[""]},"credits":{"by":[{"name":"Marvin Joseph"}]},"credits_caption_display":"A woman walks her dogs through a flooded area of Annapolis in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy in 2012. (Marvin Joseph/The Washington Post)","distributor":{"category":"staff"},"height":3653,"subtype":"StaffPhoto","taxonomy":{},"type":"image","url":"https://arc-anglerfish-washpost-prod-washpost.s3.amazonaws.com/public/M3UQEQD6YQI6ZPYC7HREZTXRJE.jpg","width":6457,"originalIdx":15},{"_id":"LZQJILOSOJAHLP32EUUKQJGDXA","additional_properties":{},"content":"In years past, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/08/23/tennessee-floods-show-pressing-climate-danger-across-america-wall-water/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003epowerful storms pushing water up shorelines\u003c/a\u003e were the primary drivers of flooding along coasts. But as surging seas raise the level of high tides, communities from the Gulf Coast and the Pacific Northwest to the beaches of Hawaii and the barrier islands of North Carolina increasingly suffer from “sunny day” floods, when saltwater bubbles up from storm drains and spills into streets without a drop of rain.","type":"text","originalIdx":16},{"_id":"CBJ5HQIY7BEHFKQBB3RD2ALSPU","additional_properties":{},"content":"A \u003ca href=\"https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/2021_State_of_High_Tide_Flooding_and_Annual_Outlook_Final.pdf\" target=_blank\u003ereport \u003c/a\u003ereleased last year by Sweet and his Ocean Service colleagues found that U.S. coastlines experience twice as much high-tide flooding as they did just 20 years ago.","type":"text","originalIdx":17},{"_id":"YOGEF6YMNFFFJODFA7JNHV7QKM","additional_properties":{},"content":"By the middle of the century, the new NOAA analysis finds, minor high-tide flooding events could happen more than 10 times a year. More significant and destructive events, which currently have about a 4 percent chance of happening in a given year, could occur twice a decade.","type":"text","originalIdx":18},{"_id":"RW3US72PY5GKZAYTGCUSPUQE3M","additional_properties":{},"content":"“What we are trying to communicate to folks is these are real-life impacts that will influence their day-to-day decision-making,” Sweet said.","type":"text","originalIdx":19},{"_id":"TW23ELDJJFETLBYHXRF4WIXATA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Coastal communities must start planning for regular inundation, scientists warned, especially in places where coastal development and sinking land compound the risks of sea level rise.","type":"text","originalIdx":20},{"_id":"DFXTJGRBSFDL5BPGYD5HI5ACHE","additional_properties":{},"content":"Storm and wastewater systems may need to be upgraded to cope with the influx of seawater. Homes and important infrastructure located within the new upper bounds of high tides might have to relocate.","type":"text","originalIdx":21},{"_id":"KQ3HAQGSBBH7PHPJI6TJ5QKC6M","additional_properties":{},"content":"The consequences could go beyond floods. Saltwater threatens to infiltrate coastal aquifers, affecting water quality and \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/ruined-crops-salty-soil-how-rising-seas-are-poisoning-north-carolinas-farmland/2019/03/01/2e26b83e-28ce-11e9-8eef-0d74f4bf0295_story.html\" target=\"_blank\"\u003esterilizing farm fields\u003c/a\u003e. The septic systems used in many coastal communities \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/12/17/climate-solutions-sewage/\" target=\"_blank\"\u003ewon’t be able to safely handle waste\u003c/a\u003e as water tables rise.","type":"text","originalIdx":22},{"_id":"MMHAX4MB7NDHRNNOMXE4FYJGEA","additional_properties":{},"content":"Ports could see severe damage, said NOAA National Ocean Service Director Nicole LeBoeuf — disrupting supply chains and raising costs even for people who live hundreds of miles from coastlines.","type":"text","originalIdx":23},{"_id":"QE5OMMECLBEM7IFW6KNXYVW6SM","additional_properties":{"keywords":[]},"credits":{"by":[{}]},"credits_caption_display":"The rate of minor high-tide flooding and sea level rise, in meters, from 98 NOAA tide gauges along U.S. coastlines outside Alaska. Tuesday’s report makes clear that a certain amount of sea level rise is essentially guaranteed based on the world’s past emissions, Dahl said that reality only underscores the importance of reducing greenhouse gas pollution.","type":"text","originalIdx":25},{"_id":"REYGA3A6HZEFPHEKO26EFGWQ4M","additional_properties":{},"content":"“The fact that there’s this locked-in sea level rise is not a reason to throw up our hands and say there’s nothing we can do about this, because there absolutely is,” she said. “This decade we’re in right now is one of the most consequential decades for our climate future.”","type":"text","originalIdx":26},{"_id":"OR7376IWXFA4TIB2XTF2PZFRUQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"That is because only by acting rapidly to reduce global emissions can the world limit Earth’s warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) compared with preindustrial levels — the most ambitious goal of the Paris climate agreement.","type":"text","originalIdx":27},{"_id":"2ZEDSTJNMJD3ND7PCQUNBB2XJI","additional_properties":{},"content":"If nations fail to hit that target, she said, it risks destabilizing the Antarctic ice sheet and creating conditions for catastrophic amounts of sea level rise in the future.","type":"text","originalIdx":28},{"_id":"IRHYUST5PRACTCRVZ4Y5WT5SJQ","additional_properties":{},"content":"“It’s really critical that we start bringing our emissions down quickly and steeply,” Dahl said, “so that we don’t get anywhere near those tipping points.”","type":"text","originalIdx":29},{"_id":"JWRZHYCYWJE6LESTYANE2P76UI","additional_properties":{},"content":"The reports finds that if warming exceeds 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, there’s at least a 50 percent chance of sea level rise exceeding 1.6 feet on average globally by 2100. With 3 to 5 degrees Celsius of warming, that likelihood balloons to 80 to 99 percent. The sea level rise in the United States would be near or higher than the global average.","type":"text","originalIdx":30},{"_id":"VJXAPABLPNCLNGMWJLVCSRU2O4","additional_properties":{},"content":"Compared with NOAA’s sea level rise projections made in 2017, the new estimates are largely unchanged through 2100. However, the expected rate of sea level rise is slightly slower through 2050, before accelerating toward the end of the century. The agency also eliminated an “extreme” scenario of over eight feet of sea level rise by 2100 that it now considers implausible.","type":"text","originalIdx":31},{"_id":"RDCREDFFEJBIPMJ52PLEANMHNI","additional_properties":{},"content":"Sign up for the latest news about climate change, energy and the environment, delivered every Thursday","type":"interstitial_link","url":"https://subscribe.washingtonpost.com/newsletters/#/bundle/energy?method=SURL\u0026location=ART","originalIdx":32},{"_id":"DU5HCZBT6FAJ3EKUZVOHBGKYZU","additional_properties":{},"content":"Reide Corbett, dean of Integrated Coastal Programs at East Carolina University and executive director at Coastal Studies Institute, said the NOAA report is important because it so clearly and definitively details a real-world threat posed by climate change.","type":"text","originalIdx":33},{"_id":"2IDEGVZMFBCOVHEXFFTARZCO2Q","additional_properties":{},"content":"“We need to make people understand this isn’t just a bunch of scientists talking and arm-waving. This is really happening, and it’s happening on time scales that matter to the individual,” said Corbett, who was not involved in the study.","type":"text","originalIdx":34},{"_id":"2M3QHT3WVJDKTNYAY7DLPQOZ3I","additional_properties":{},"content":"“If we’re talking about 2050 — for someone buying a house today, that’s within the range of their mortgage.”","type":"text","originalIdx":35},{"_id":"RFHZG5QDG5BONHWK2RP5K2ADPE","additional_properties":{},"content":"For Corbett, who lives on the flood-prone Outer Banks of North Carolina, the prospect of sea level rise is deeply personal. readabilityObject.title: Sea level to rise one foot along U.S. coastlines by 2050, government report finds
readabilityObject.content:
The shorelines of the United States are projected to face an additional foot of rising seas over the next three decades, intensifying the threat of flooding and erosion to coastal communities across the country, according to a report released Tuesday by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

Human-caused climate change, driven mostly by the burning of fossil fuels, has accelerated global sea level rise to the fastest rate in more than 3,000 years. The report by NOAA, NASA and five other federal agencies — updating a study from 2017 — predicts that ocean levels along U.S. coasts will increase as much by 2050 as they did over the past century.

This amount of water battering the coasts “will create a profound increase in the frequency of coastal flooding, even in the absence of storms or heavy rainfall,” NOAA said.

“We’re unfortunately headed for a flood regime shift,” said William Sweet, an oceanographer at the NOAA National Ocean Service and the nation’s top scientist on sea level rise. “There will be water in the streets unless action is taken in more and more communities.”

Drawing on data from tidal gauges and satellite imagery as well as cutting-edge models from the most recent United Nations report on climate change, the NOAA analysis gives decade-by-decade projections for sea-level rise for all U.S. states and territories over the next 100 years. Advances in ice sheet modeling and better observational data allowed the authors to give more definitive near-term projections than ever before, Sweet said.

Even if the world takes swift action to curb carbon emissions, he said, the trajectory for sea level rise “is more or less set over the next 30 years.”

Kristina Dahl, a principal climate scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists, said research she and colleagues have done suggest that 10 to 12 inches of sea level rise by 2050 would put roughly 140,000 homes at risk of “chronic inundation,” or flooding every other week on average.

Already, she said, high-tide flooding in places such as Charleston, S.C., has quadrupled in frequency since the 1970s. Other regions, from Louisiana to New Jersey to the Eastern Shore of Maryland, have wrestled with flooding that has become more common and costly.

“They’re already having to make difficult decisions or major investments to cope with the flooding they are seeing,” said Dahl, who was not involved in Tuesday’s report. While other coastal communities have avoided major impacts, “they will have to start grappling with these same kind of issues.”

Looking ahead to the end of the century, the amount of planet-warming pollution people release into the atmosphere could mean the difference between sea levels stabilizing at about two feet above the historical average or surging by almost eight feet, NOAA reports.

“This report is a wake-up call for the U.S., but it’s a wake-up call with a silver lining,” NOAA Administrator Rick Spinrad told journalists in a teleconference Tuesday. “It provides us with information needed to act now to best position ourselves for the future.”

In years past, powerful storms pushing water up shorelines were the primary drivers of flooding along coasts. But as surging seas raise the level of high tides, communities from the Gulf Coast and the Pacific Northwest to the beaches of Hawaii and the barrier islands of North Carolina increasingly suffer from “sunny day” floods, when saltwater bubbles up from storm drains and spills into streets without a drop of rain.

A report released last year by Sweet and his Ocean Service colleagues found that U.S. coastlines experience twice as much high-tide flooding as they did just 20 years ago.

By the middle of the century, the new NOAA analysis finds, minor high-tide flooding events could happen more than 10 times a year. More significant and destructive events, which currently have about a 4 percent chance of happening in a given year, could occur twice a decade.

“What we are trying to communicate to folks is these are real-life impacts that will influence their day-to-day decision-making,” Sweet said.

Coastal communities must start planning for regular inundation, scientists warned, especially in places where coastal development and sinking land compound the risks of sea level rise.

Storm and wastewater systems may need to be upgraded to cope with the influx of seawater. Homes and important infrastructure located within the new upper bounds of high tides might have to relocate.

The consequences could go beyond floods. Saltwater threatens to infiltrate coastal aquifers, affecting water quality and sterilizing farm fields. The septic systems used in many coastal communities won’t be able to safely handle waste as water tables rise.

Ports could see severe damage, said NOAA National Ocean Service Director Nicole LeBoeuf — disrupting supply chains and raising costs even for people who live hundreds of miles from coastlines.

While Tuesday’s report makes clear that a certain amount of sea level rise is essentially guaranteed based on the world’s past emissions, Dahl said that reality only underscores the importance of reducing greenhouse gas pollution.

“The fact that there’s this locked-in sea level rise is not a reason to throw up our hands and say there’s nothing we can do about this, because there absolutely is,” she said. “This decade we’re in right now is one of the most consequential decades for our climate future.”

That is because only by acting rapidly to reduce global emissions can the world limit Earth’s warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) compared with preindustrial levels — the most ambitious goal of the Paris climate agreement.

If nations fail to hit that target, she said, it risks destabilizing the Antarctic ice sheet and creating conditions for catastrophic amounts of sea level rise in the future.

“It’s really critical that we start bringing our emissions down quickly and steeply,” Dahl said, “so that we don’t get anywhere near those tipping points.”

The reports finds that if warming exceeds 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, there’s at least a 50 percent chance of sea level rise exceeding 1.6 feet on average globally by 2100. With 3 to 5 degrees Celsius of warming, that likelihood balloons to 80 to 99 percent. The sea level rise in the United States would be near or higher than the global average.

Compared with NOAA’s sea level rise projections made in 2017, the new estimates are largely unchanged through 2100. However, the expected rate of sea level rise is slightly slower through 2050, before accelerating toward the end of the century. The agency also eliminated an “extreme” scenario of over eight feet of sea level rise by 2100 that it now considers implausible.

Reide Corbett, dean of Integrated Coastal Programs at East Carolina University and executive director at Coastal Studies Institute, said the NOAA report is important because it so clearly and definitively details a real-world threat posed by climate change.

“We need to make people understand this isn’t just a bunch of scientists talking and arm-waving. This is really happening, and it’s happening on time scales that matter to the individual,” said Corbett, who was not involved in the study.

“If we’re talking about 2050 — for someone buying a house today, that’s within the range of their mortgage.”

For Corbett, who lives on the flood-prone Outer Banks of North Carolina, the prospect of sea level rise is deeply personal. Just last week, he said, beach erosion caused a house in nearby Rodanthe to collapse into the sea.

He hoped the NOAA findings will spur vulnerable communities to invest in adaptation measures — restoring ecosystems that help hold back floodwaters, rerouting roads and bridges to steer away from the most vulnerable spots. In some cases, he said, communities will have to make hard decisions about what places are worth protecting and when it’s time to retreat.

“We need to really start working through these challenging conversations now,” he said. “Not right after the next storm, but before.”

Homes and important infrastructure located within the new upper bounds of high tides might have to relocate.The consequences could go beyond floods. Saltwater threatens to infiltrate coastal aquifers, affecting water quality and sterilizing farm fields. The septic systems used in many coastal communities won’t be able to safely handle waste as water tables rise.Ports could see severe damage, said NOAA National Ocean Service Director Nicole LeBoeuf — disrupting supply chains and raising costs even for people who live hundreds of miles from coastlines.While Tuesday’s report makes clear that a certain amount of sea level rise is essentially guaranteed based on the world’s past emissions, Dahl said that reality only underscores the importance of reducing greenhouse gas pollution.“The fact that there’s this locked-in sea level rise is not a reason to throw up our hands and say there’s nothing we can do about this, because there absolutely is,” she said. “This decade we’re in right now is one of the most consequential decades for our climate future.”That is because only by acting rapidly to reduce global emissions can the world limit Earth’s warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 Fahrenheit) compared with preindustrial levels — the most ambitious goal of the Paris climate agreement.If nations fail to hit that target, she said, it risks destabilizing the Antarctic ice sheet and creating conditions for catastrophic amounts of sea level rise in the future.“It’s really critical that we start bringing our emissions down quickly and steeply,” Dahl said, “so that we don’t get anywhere near those tipping points.”The reports finds that if warming exceeds 2 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels, there’s at least a 50 percent chance of sea level rise exceeding 1.6 feet on average globally by 2100. With 3 to 5 degrees Celsius of warming, that likelihood balloons to 80 to 99 percent. The sea level rise in the United States would be near or higher than the global average.Compared with NOAA’s sea level rise projections made in 2017, the new estimates are largely unchanged through 2100. However, the expected rate of sea level rise is slightly slower through 2050, before accelerating toward the end of the century. The agency also eliminated an “extreme” scenario of over eight feet of sea level rise by 2100 that it now considers implausible.Reide Corbett, dean of Integrated Coastal Programs at East Carolina University and executive director at Coastal Studies Institute, said the NOAA report is important because it so clearly and definitively details a real-world threat posed by climate change.“We need to make people understand this isn’t just a bunch of scientists talking and arm-waving. This is really happening, and it’s happening on time scales that matter to the individual,” said Corbett, who was not involved in the study.“If we’re talking about 2050 — for someone buying a house today, that’s within the range of their mortgage.”For Corbett, who lives on the flood-prone Outer Banks of North Carolina, the prospect of sea level rise is deeply personal. Just last week, he said, beach erosion caused a house in nearby Rodanthe to collapse into the sea.He hoped the NOAA findings will spur vulnerable communities to invest in adaptation measures — restoring ecosystems that help hold back floodwaters, rerouting roads and bridges to steer away from the most vulnerable spots. In some cases, he said, communities will have to make hard decisions about what places are worth protecting and when it’s time to retreat.“We need to really start working through these challenging conversations now,” he said. “Not right after the next storm, but before.”
readabilityObject.excerpt: Sea levels along the United States' shorelines will increase as much by 2050 as they did over the past century, according to a report from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

metadata.firstParagraph: The shorelines of the United States are projected to face an additional foot of rising seas over the next three decades, intensifying the threat of flooding and erosion to coastal communities across the country, according to a report released Tuesday by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.
